Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Impact of Pregnancy on the Mechanics of Vaginal Tissue

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) encompass a number of medical conditions including stress urinary and fecal incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse. Although not often discussed, these conditions are extremely common, with more than 50% of parous women having some degree of a PFD during their lifetime and 11% of women requiring surgery. These disorders severely alter the quality of life of women often leading to isolation and depression. To someone not entirely familiar with internal female pelvic anatomy, it may appear that the vagina is no more important than the rectum or urethra in the development of these disorders. However, the vagina is the primary support structure for the urethra, bladder, uterus, and rectum. The vagina is, in turn, supported by a combination of muscle and connective tissues. A direct insult to the vagina and/or its supportive muscles and tissues compromises the function of other pelvic organs. Thus, it should come as no surprise that excessive stretching and tearing of the vagina during labor and vaginal delivery are predisposing factors for the development of PFDs. It is still unclear, however, which of the structural and mechanical alterations that occur in vaginal tissue during pregnancy predispose women to the development of PFDs.

This collaborative project aims to characterize, for the first time, the mechanisms of stretch induced damage and tear propagation in virgin and pregnant rat vaginal tissue. A comprehensive set of ring tests will be conducted to determine the functional role of the tissue?s constituents (collagen, elastin, and smooth muscle cells) on both the active and passive mechanics of the vagina. Planar biaxial tests will be performed to study the tear propagation process. The results of these tests will guide the development of a new constitutive model that will capture the active and passive mechanical response of the vaginal tissue, including stretch-induced damage. The constitutive model will be implemented into a finite element code especially developed to simulate damage and tear propagation of vaginal tissue. For validation, three-dimensional in-vivo experimental data, which are collected by conducting inflation tests that simulate a birth injury within a state-of-the-art 7T micro-MRI, will be utilized.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pelvic floor disorders encompass a number of medical conditions including stress urinary and fecal incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse. Although not often discussed, these conditions are extremely common, with more than 50% of parous women having some degree of pelvic floor disorders during their lifetime and 11% of women requiring surgery. To someone not entirely familiar with internal female pelvic anatomy, it may appear that the vagina is no more important than the rectum or urethra in the development of these issues. However, the vagina is the primary mechanism of support for the urethra, bladder, uterus, and rectum. The vagina is, in turn, supported by a combination of muscle and connective tissues. A direct insult to the vagina and/or its supportive tissues compromises support to the other pelvic organs as well. Thus, it should come as no surprise that excessive stretching and tearing of the vagina are predisposing factors for the development of pelvic floor disorder. 

This collaborative project characterized, for the first time, the mechanisms of stretch-induced damage and tear propagation in vaginal tissue of large and small animal models. A comprehensive set of mechanical tests was conducted to determine the impact of stretch-induced damage on both the active and passive mechanics of the vagina and the tear propagation process was also investigated. This project demonstrated that (a) the vagina contracts significantly more along the longitudinal direction than in the circumferential direction in response to KCl, (b) rupture of the vagina consistently occurs in the circumferential direction by tearing along the longitudinal direction, (c) the organization of collagen fibers confers high tear resistance to the vaginal tissue and controls the tear behavior. Collectively, the outcome of this research could potentially guide the development of new preventive measures and transform surgical reparative procedures for pelvic floor disorders by providing new insight into the complex mechanics of vaginal tissue. Research and education activities were seamlessly integrated to promote scientific discovery about the complex mechanical function of vaginal tissue and increase awareness about pelvic floor disorders. A summer camp, called STEMABILITY, was offered to high school students with disabilities and their parents to facilitate their transition to college. Several undergraduate and graduate students, especially from underrepresented groups, participated in the research and education activities related to this project. The findings of these efforts were disseminated on the web, published in peer-reviewed journals, and presented at national and international conferences. 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2020
Modified by: Raffaella De Vita
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Pelvic floor disorders encompass a number of medical conditions including stress urinary and fecal incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse. Although not often discussed, these conditions are extremely common, with more than 50% of parous women having some degree of pelvic floor disorders during their lifetime and 11% of women requiring surgery. To someone not entirely familiar with internal female pelvic anatomy, it may appear that the vagina is no more important than the rectum or urethra in the development of these issues. However, the vagina is the primary mechanism of support for the urethra, bladder, uterus, and rectum. The vagina is, in turn, supported by a combination of muscle and connective tissues. A direct insult to the vagina and/or its supportive tissues compromises support to the other pelvic organs as well. Thus, it should come as no surprise that excessive stretching and tearing of the vagina are predisposing factors for the development of pelvic floor disorder. This collaborative project characterized, for the first time, the mechanisms of stretch-induced damage and tear propagation in vaginal tissue of large and small animal models. A comprehensive set of mechanical tests was conducted to determine the impact of stretch-induced damage on both the active and passive mechanics of the vagina and the tear propagation process was also investigated. This project demonstrated that (a) the vagina contracts significantly more along the longitudinal direction than in the circumferential direction in response to KCl, (b) rupture of the vagina consistently occurs in the circumferential direction by tearing along the longitudinal direction, (c) the organization of collagen fibers confers high tear resistance to the vaginal tissue and controls the tear behavior. Collectively, the outcome of this research could potentially guide the development of new preventive measures and transform surgical reparative procedures for pelvic floor disorders by providing new insight into the complex mechanics of vaginal tissue. Research and education activities were seamlessly integrated to promote scientific discovery about the complex mechanical function of vaginal tissue and increase awareness about pelvic floor disorders. A summer camp, called STEMABILITY, was offered to high school students with disabilities and their parents to facilitate their transition to college. Several undergraduate and graduate students, especially from underrepresented groups, participated in the research and education activities related to this project. The findings of these efforts were disseminated on the web, published in peer-reviewed journals, and presented at national and international conferences.
